revision.text:
'''"Aces of Action"''' was the informal nickname given to the movie teaming of [[Richard Arlen]] and [[Andy Devine]]. They made a number of low budget action films together for Universal.<ref>Actor Richard Arlen Dies; Swashbuckled to Stardom Los Angeles Times 29 Mar 1976: b1</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article174797499 |title=Advertising |newspaper=[[The Uralla Times]] |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=21 August 1941 |accessdate=13 June 2018 |page=1 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In February 1939 Universal announced they would make seven "outdoor pictures" starring the duo over the next year, all produced by Ben Pivar.<ref>SCREEN NEWS HERE AND IN HOLLYWOOD: Universal Selects Arlen and Devine for Leads in Series of 7 Outdoor Pictures New York Times 11 Feb 1939: 18.</ref><ref>Arlen, Devine Paired in Universal Series Schallert, Edwin. Los Angeles Times11 Feb 1939: A9.</ref> The films were well received and the series continued until Arlen left Universal for [[Pine-Thomas Productions]].
Universal then tried Devine in a series of other "buddy" comedies, teaming him with Leo Carillo and Broderick Crawford. ==Films== ===Richard Arlen & Andy Devine=== *''[[Mutiny on the Blackhawk]]'' (1939) *''[[Tropic Fury]]'' (1939) *''[[Legion of Lost Flyers]]'' (1939) *''[[Man from Montreal]]'' (1939) *''[[Danger on Wheels]]'' (1940) *''[[Hot Steel]]'' (1940) *''[[Black Diamonds (film)|Black Diamonds]]'' (1940) *''[[The Leather Pushers (1940 film)|The Leather Pushers]]'' (1940) *''[[The Devil's Pipeline]]'' (1940) *''[[Lucky Devils (1941 film)|Lucky Devils]]'' (1941) *''[[Mutiny in the Arctic]]'' (1941) *''[[Men of the Timberland]]'' (1941) *''[[Raiders of the Desert]]'' (1941) *''[[A Dangerous Game (1941 film)|A Dangerous Game]]'' (1941) ===Leo Carillo & Andy Devine=== *''[[The Kid from Kansas]]'' (1941) - and Dick Foran *''[[Road Agent (1941 film)|Road Agent]]'' (1941) *''[[Unseen Enemy]]'' (1942) *''[[Escape from Hong Kong]]'' (1942) - and Don Terry *''[[Danger in the Pacific]]'' (1942) - and Don Terry *''[[Top Sergeant (film)|Top Sergeant]]'' (1942) - and Don Terry *''[[Timber (1942 film)|Timber!]]'' (1942) - and [[Dan Dailey]]
===Broderick Crawford & Andy Devine=== *''[[South of Tahiti]]'' (1941) - and [[Brian Donlevy]] *''[[North to the Klondike]]'' (1941) - and [[Lon Chaney Jr]]
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Film series]] {{action-film-stub}}

{{Refimprove|date=October 2013}} {{Italic title}}
'''Adloyada''' ([[Hebrew]]: '''עדלאידע''' or '''עדלידע''', lit. "Until one no longer knows") is a humorous procession held in [[Israel]] on the [[Jewish holidays|Jewish holiday]] of [[Purim]] (or in [[Shushan Purim]] the second day of Purim, commanded to be celebrated in "walled cities", nowadays only in [[Jerusalem]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chabad.org/holidays/purim/article_cdo/aid/645278/jewish/Walled-Cities.htm|title=Shushan Purim - Why Jerusalem celebrates a day later|website=www.chabad.org}}</ref>
The Adloyada parade is a tradition dating back to the early days of [[Tel Aviv]], in 1912. During the days of the [[Yishuv]], the Adloyada was a mass event; it was resumed after the state of Israel was established.
The name is derived from the rabbinic saying in the [[Megillah (Talmud)|Talmud]] that one should revel on Purim by drinking "until one no longer knows" (''ad de-lo yada'', [[Aramaic]]: עַד דְּלָא יָדַע) the difference between "blessed be [[Mordecai]]" and "cursed be [[Haman (Bible)|Haman]]".<ref>{{cite news|title=ADLOYADA|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0001_0_00472.html}}[[Jewish Virtual Library]]</ref><ref name=Meg7b>{{cite web|url=http://halakhah.com/pdf/moed/Megilah.pdf|title=Meg. 7b|publisher=}}</ref><ref>Shoshana Kordova, [http://www.haaretz.com/jewish/features/word-of-the-day-adloyada.premium-1.504852 Word of the Day Adloyada], ''[[Haaretz]]'', February 21, 2013 </ref>
==History== [[File:Adloyada 1956.jpg|thumb|left|"[[David Ben-Gurion]]" and "[[Gamal Abdel Nasser]]" in the 1956 ''Adloyada'' parade in [[Tel Aviv]] ]]
[[File:Flickr - Government Press Office (GPO) - A HUGE DOLL IN THE FIGURE OF DAVID BEN GURION, PARTICIPATING IN THE ADLOYADA PARADE.jpg|thumb|left|[[David Ben-Gurion]] float at the ''Adloyada'' parade, 1998]] [[File:PikiWiki Israel 12251 purim festival in holon 2011.jpg|thumb|left|''Adloyada'' carnival in [[Holon]], 2011]]
The first Adloyada parade was initiated by [[Avraham Aldema]], a teacher and co-founder of "[[Hevre Trasek]]", and was held in [[Tel Aviv]] during Purim in 1912. This parade was characterized by provocative costumes and pranks. According to several testimonies, the parade of 1912 was very colorful and beautiful. It consisted of giant puppets, a marching band and hundreds of children wearing their Purim costumes. Throughout the years, the parade became a permanent tradition of Purim. These events were held parallel to the famous celebrations that were organized by [[Baruch Agadati]]. Agadati's merriments had become extremely profitable, and so were criticized harshly by "Hevre Trasek" for being over commercialized.
Tel Aviv's Adloyadas were complemented with luxurious Purim [[Ball (dance)|balls]], created by Baruch Agadati. Throughout the years, the parades were expanded and their path was moved from [[Theodor Herzl|Herzl]] Street to [[Allenby Street]] and to [[Ibn Gabirol Street]] upon the establishment of the state of [[Israel]].
During the 1930s, every Adloyada had a specific theme, for example the [[tribes of Israel]] (in 1934), and the achievements of the [[Yishuv]]. During that time, [[Tel Aviv]]'s Purim events attracted many tourists from all around Israel and from abroad.
As opposed to [[European states]], where carnivals were a means to break loose and consisted of extreme licentiousness, aggressiveness and protest, the Tel Aviv event had different features. The main carnival, despite its new name ''Adloyada'', was characterized by a "proper" behavior. The municipality issued annual limitations on the Purim celebrations such as a prohibition to use [[explosives]] and dress up in costumes that may offend the [[Jewish religion]] or the Israeli nation. Despite the censorship and the sanctions, there were a few costumes and parades that didn't obey the rules and used the public festivity to express social protest, and thus made their mark on the city.
During the 1928 carnival, with the theme "10 years to the national home", Hevre Trasek presented a 10-candle [[Menorah (Temple)|Menorah]] (as a symbol to Balfour's statement); instead of candles there was a rude gesture and the sign "free Aliya, Jews in the top clerical work". In one of the "Menorah" balls (Menorah was a club founded by veterans) in 1927, [[Avraham Atkind]] won the costume competition for his costume: "balancing the clerk's salary in the Palestine government". Atkind's hat had a scale and a photograph of the residence of the British commissioner in the magnificent [[Augusta Victoria Hospital|Augusta Victoria]] building in [[Mount Scopus]], as well as a poem, expressing the discontent of the gap between the British clerk's salary and the salaries of local Israelis from all ethnic groups.
[[Gdud Meginei Hasafa]] (Hebrew: גדוד מגיני השפה, [[Battalion for the Defence of the Language]]), an organization in Tel Aviv fighting to make Hebrew the common language in [[Mandatory Palestine]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://via.lib.harvard.edu/via/deliver/deepcontent?recordId=olvwork464392 |title=Legion of the Defenders of the Language |website= Harvard University Library |publisher= President and Fellows of Harvard College |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/archive/Pages/gmh.aspx |language= Hebrew |title= גדוד מגיני השפה |trans-title=Battalion of Defenders of the Language|publisher= The Academy of the Hebrew Language, האקדמיה ללשון העברית |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> used Purim to present and to flood the streets with written propaganda. The Gdud documents were distributed during the Purim carnival. In addition, the Gdud held an annual costume competition with the theme of the superiority and importance of the [[Hebrew]] language. In the carnival of 1929, the Gdud presented the "tower of [[Babylon]]"; a tower on top of a horse-drawn cart with the slogan "revival of the language, revival of the people" and "words can kill".
In the main carnival of 1933, there was a puppet of [[Hitler]] riding a horse, as part of the parade. On its neck there was a sign saying; "kill Jews" and next to it there were 2 Jews bleeding to death. The German consul in Jerusalem sent a letter to Tel Aviv Mayor [[Meir Dizengoff]] in the matter and demanded an apology, but Dizengoff replied that Purim is a stage for free speech of public opinion. A year later, a huge puppet was presented with a [[swastika]] on its back.
In 1935, a giant puppet was built, named "the profiteering monster". On the day of festivities, a public trial was held for the puppet, during which Dizengoff, [[Menachem Ussishkin]], [[Chaim Weizmann]] and [[Yehoshua Hankin]] ruled that the monster was guilty of various crimes including fraud, spending the people's wealth, and destruction of the achievements of the pioneers.
In one of the later carnivals, a group of people dressed as [[Ku Klux Klan]] members in order to protest racism in the [[United States]].
While Purim festivals became central public events in the 1920s and 1930s for expressing current social issues, the holiday events, overall and despite exceptions, were aimed to strengthen national messages and dominant ideologies. As opposed to its Biblical origin, where Purim constitutes "an opposite world" (the fool becomes the king and the king is presented as a fool around town), in [[Tel Aviv]] the holiday was institutionalized to conserve the social hierarchy and the parades were led by the city's mayor [[Meir Dizengoff]], astride a horse.
During the [[Second World War]], the Adloyada tradition was extinguished.
==After the establishment of the State of Israel== The Adloyada tradition was renewed in the Purim of 1955. In the late sixties, the tradition disintegrated in Tel Aviv and the parade was transferred to [[Holon]], although it lacked the unrefined feature of events in the small [[Tel Aviv]].
In the 80’s an [[ArchiParhiTura]] (also spelled ArchiParchiTura; Hebrew: ארכיפרחיטורה) was introduced in [[Haifa]]. It was a Purim parade which had giant displays made by [[Technion]] architecture students ("ArchiParhiTura" is the Hebrew combination of the words architecture and "archi parhi"- which is the biblical expression of vagabond) and set on trucks. The parade went through [[Theodor Herzl|Herzl]] Street in the [[Hadar Hacarmel]] area and was accompanied by an orchestra.
In the last few years, an attempt was made to return to tradition and resume the Adloyada as an important main event in different cities.
==The name ''Adloyada''== In the beginning, the parade was called "carnival". In 1923, a competition was held in order to find a new permanent name for the parade. Out of 300 submissions, author [[Isaac Dov Berkowitz]]'s entry ''Adloyada'' was chosen.
Adloyada means reaching a state of total intoxication. The expression comes from the Aramaic expression stated by [[Rabbah bar Nahmani|Rabbah]] in the Babylonian Talmud, Tractate Megilla: "It is the duty of a man to mellow himself ... on Purim until he cannot tell the difference between 'cursed be Haman' and 'blessed be Mordecai'." <ref name=Meg7b /> This means that people should drink on Purim until he reaches a state of not being able to distinguish between the evil Haman and the blessed Mordecai.
Among the other submitted suggestions were [[Hayim Nahman Bialik]]'s entry "Pura", [[Shaul Tchernichovsky|Tchernichovsky]]'s entry "Astoret" and [[Avraham Shlonsky]]'s entry "Tzahalula".
==See also== *[[Culture of Israel]] ==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commonscatinline}} *[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0001_0_00472.html ADLOYADA], [[Jewish Virtual Library]] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ImekKsGi5M Purim Adloyada Holon 2013] YouTube * [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4348375,00.html Green Purim parties cause for celebration] Ynet News.com

{{Infobox artifact | name = Ateni Theotokos Church Georgian inscription | image = [[File:ატენის ღვთისმშობლის მცირეგუმბათიანი ეკლესიის წარწერა.JPG|280px]] | image2 = | image_caption = | material = | size = | writing = [[Georgian language]] inscriptions written in a [[Georgian script]] | created = 982–989 | discovered = 1940 | location = | id = }} The '''Ateni Theotokos Church inscription''' ({{lang-ka|ატენის ღვთისმშობლის ეკლესიის წარწერა}}) is the [[Georgian language]] inscription written in the Georgian ''[[Asomtavruli]]'' script on the Ateni ''[[Theotokos]]'' Church, a [[basilica]] located in the village of Didi Ateni, [[Gori Municipality]], [[Shida Kartli]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. The inscriptions are dated 982–989 AD. The inscription mentions Rati I and Liparit II, [[Duchy of Kldekari|Dukes of Kldekari]].N. Shoshiashvili, Corpus of Georgian inscriptions, I, Tbilisi, 1980, pp. 202–203L. Rcheulishvili, Ateni Low-domed Church, Georgian Art, I, Tbilisi, 1942, pp. 33–37Kornelius Danelia, Zurab Sarjveladze, Georgian Paleography. Tbilisi, 1997, pp. 42–43 ==Inscription== {{cquote|ႵႤ ႠႣႨႣႤ ႭႰႱႠ
ႥႤ ႺႾႭႥႰႤႡႠႱႠ
ႠႵႠ ჄႭႰႺႨႤႪႤႡ
Ⴐ ႣႠ ႼႤ ႸႬႱႠ ႱႳႪ
ႨႤႡႰ ႰႠႲ ႤႰႨႱႧ
ႠႥႨ ႻႤ ႨႢႨ ႪႮႰႲ
ႤႰႨႱႧႥႨႱႠႨ ႰႪႬ
ႠႶႠႸႤႬႠ ႤႱႤ ႱႠႾ
ႪႨ ႶႧႨႱႠႨ ႣႠ ႡႽႤႨ
ႺႠႧႠႨ ႼႨ ႤႩႪႤႱႨ
ႠႨ ႱႠႪႭႺႥႤႪႠႣ
ႱႳႪႨႱႠ ႫႧႨႱႠ}} *'''Translation:''' "Jesus Christ, have mercy on both of the worldly lives, bodily and spiritual, of Rati [[Eristavi]], son of Liparit Eristavi, who built this house of God as a rock of Sky, a holy Church, for praying for their souls." ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Georgian language]] [[Category:Archaeological artifacts]] [[Category:Georgian inscriptions]] [[Category:980s]] [[Category:10th-century inscriptions]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Baptism of Christ by Cima da Conegliano.jpg | title=Baptsm of Christ | artist=Cima da Conegliano | year=1492 | medium=Oil on panel | height_metric=350 | width_metric=210 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=[[San Giovanni in Bragora]], [[Venice]] }} '''''Baptism of Christ''''' is a painting by Italian Renaissance painter [[Cima da Conegliano]], dating from 1492. It is housed in the church of [[San Giovanni in Bragora]] in [[Venice]].
==Description==
The painting portrays Christ at the center of the scene, standing with joined hands. His attitude is that of humble submission to baptism, which is being given him by [[Saint John the Baptist]], who appears on the right.
At the left are three angels with Christ's garments, in red and blue colors, which he will use after the baptism. The scene is completed by an angelic choir in the sky, and a generic oriental city on a spur in the left, behind the angels, while another one is visible in the far background.
==External links== *[http://www.sgbattistainbragora.it/index.php?id=16&lang=it Page at the church's website] {{it icon}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1492 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Cima da Conegliano]] [[Category:Paintings of the Baptism of Christ|Cima da Conegliano]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Paintings in Venice]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Schwarzwaelderin in Tracht um 1900.jpg|thumb|Woman in the Black Forest, around 1900]] [[File:Lallemand et Hart N° 46 Gemeinde Gutach 1864 02.jpg|thumb|Ludovico Wolfgang Hart, Three Girls of Gutach, 1864]] [[File:Théodore Valerio Hornberg.jpg|thumb|Théodore Valerio, Couple of Hornberg, 1841]]
A '''Bollenhut''' is a formal headdress worn since {{circa}}1750 by Protestant women as part of their folk costume or ''[[Tracht]]'' in the three neighbouring [[Black Forest]] villages of [[Gutach (Schwarzwaldbahn)|Gutach]], [[Kirnbach (Wolfach)|Kirnbach]] and [[Reichenbach (Hornberg)|Hornberg-Reichenbach]]. With its woollen [[pompom]]s, the picturesque-looking red ''Bollenhut'' has become a symbol of the [[Black Forest]] as a whole, despite its very local origins. The red pom-poms and white brim of the ''Bollenhut'' also is said to have inspired the top layer of the [[Black Forest Cake]].<ref>http://sweets.seriouseats.com/2014/01/know-your-sweets-black-forest-cake.html</ref>
== Bollenhut as part of folk costume == The broad-brimmed, whitewashed straw hat bears 14 prominent, woollen, pompoms arranged in the shape of a cross. Only eleven pompoms are visible, however, because three are covered by those on top. Unmarried women wear red pompoms, married women wear black, old women and widows wear only the mob cap. The ''Bollenhut'' can weigh up to two kilogrammes and is manufactured by female [[milliner]]s. The red ''Bollenhut'' may first be worn by girls at their [[confirmation]].
A silk [[mob cap]] is worn underneath the ''Bollenhut'', tied under the chin. Young girls before [[confirmation]] (Gutach and several neighbouring parishes were part of [[Württemberg]] until 1804 and were [[Protestant]], unlike the majority of the Black Forest) and old women only wore the mob cap.
Today the ''Bollenhut'' and associated ''Tracht'' are still worn on holidays and for traditional events. The ''Bollenhut'' and local costumes may be seen all year round e.g. in the [[Black Forest Costume Museum]] in [[Haslach im Kinzigtal]].
== Development as a Black Forest symbol == In the late 18th century, apart from several mob caps, the ''[[Schühut]]'' and ''[[Gupfhut]]'', which were customary in the County of Hauenstein, were associated with the folk costume of the Black Forest. These types of hats which were known Europe-wide gradually fell out of use by the middle of the 19th century. In 1841 following a study trip through the Black Forest, Théodore Valerio published, through the Fréres Gihaut in Paris, a [[lithograph]] of a couple from [[Hornberg]] wearing their local costume, which showed an early version of the ''Bollenhut'' for the first time in France. After Gutach was connected to the [[Black Forest Railway (Baden)|Baden Black Forest Railway]] in 1873, artists like [[Wilhelm Hasemann]], [[Curt Liebich]] and [[Fritz Reiss]] settled there, forming the "Gutach artists' colony". They portrayed the Gutach costume as an artistic subject, their works were widely distributed and shaped the image of the Black Forest. Like local author, [[Heinrich Hansjakob]], they were part of a movement of Baden folk costume. At the turn of the 20th century, particularly Hasemann's painting, ''After Going To Church'' which showed ''Bollenhut'' wearers, was widely publicized in illustrated magazines and picture postcards.<ref>Brigitte Heck: ''Ein Hut macht Karriere.''. In: Badisches Landesmuseum Karlsruhe (publ.): ''Baden! 900 Jahre – Geschichten eines Landes.'' Info-Verlag, Karlsruhe, 2012, {{ISBN|978-3-937345-56-7}}, p. 256 (Katalog zur Großen Landesausstellung)</ref>
The fame of the ''Bollenhut'' as (wrongly) generally typical of the Black Forest rose as a result of films of local life (''Heimatfilme'') in the 1950s and 1960s, particularly the 1950 film, ''[[The Black Forest Girl (1950 film)|The Black Forest Girl]]'' (''Schwarzwaldmädel''), with [[Sonja Ziemann]]. This first German colour film of the post war period is one of the most successful German films of all time with an estimated 15 million viewers.
== References == <references />
== External links == {{commons category|Bollenhut}} {{Wiktionary|Bollenhut}} *[http://www.zum.de/Faecher/G/BW/Landeskunde/rhein/volkskunde/trachten/haslachfr.htm Haslach Trachten Museum] *[http://www.mtv-reichenbach.de Reichenbach Music and Trachten Club with organisational Bollenhut Tracht]

{{Redirect|BYU}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox university | name = Brigham Young University | image_name = Brigham Young University medallion.svg | image_size = 200 | motto = ''No official motto''{{cite news|last=Walch|first=Tad|title=BYU not alone in using motto "''Enter to learn''" |url=http://deseretnews.com/dn/view/0,1249,695197761,00.html|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|date=August 4, 2007|accessdate=June 14, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130102083220/http://deseretnews.com/dn/view/0,1249,695197761,00.html|archivedate=January 2, 2013}}
Unofficial mottoes include:
''The glory of God is intelligence''Nussbaum, Martha. Cultivating Humanity. Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1997. {{ISBN|0-674-17949-8}} pp. 290.
''Enter to learn, go forth to serve''
''The world is our campus''{{cite web|title=Campus|work=About BYU|publisher=Brigham Young University|year=2007|url=http://unicomm.byu.edu/about/default.aspx?content=campus |accessdate=August 19, 2007}} | established = {{start date and age|1875|10|16}} | type = Private not-for-profit
[[Space Grant|space grant]] | religious_affiliation = [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] | endowment = $1.47 billion (2014){{cite web|title=Endowment Funds of American Universities |url=http://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d15/tables/dt15_333.90.asp?current=yes |publisher=National Center for Education Statistics}} | president = [[Kevin J Worthen]] | students = 33,517{{cite web|title=Y Facts|url=http://news.byu.edu/about|website=BYU.edu|year=2017|accessdate=September 3, 2017}} | undergrad = 30,693 | postgrad = 2,824 {{cite web|title=College Navigator - Brigham Young University|url=https://nces.ed.gov/collegenavigator/?s=UT&id=230038|work=National Center for Education Statistics|publisher=U.S. Department of Education|accessdate=September 3, 2017}} | staff = 1,200 full-time, 900 part-time | faculty = 1,264 full-time, 486 part-time | city = [[Provo, Utah|Provo]] | state = [[Utah]] | country = United States | campus = [[Suburban]], {{convert|560|acre|km2}} | former_names = Brigham Young Academy | colors = Navy Blue and White{{cite web|last=Nimer|first=Cory|title=Establishing school colors|url=https://sites.lib.byu.edu/special-collections/2015/11/24/establishing-school-colors/|publisher=Brigham Young University|date=November 24, 2015|accessdate=August 17, 2018}}{{cite web|title=Primary Colors|url=https://brand.byu.edu/guidelines/color/|publisher=Brigham Young University|accessdate=August 17, 2018}}
{{color box|#002E5D}} {{color box|#FFFFFF}} | nickname = [[BYU Cougars|Cougars]] | mascot = [[Cosmo the Cougar]] | website = {{url|www.byu.edu}} | athletics = [[NCAA Division I]] / [[NCAA Division I FBS independent schools|FBS Independent]]
[[West Coast Conference]] | logo = BYU Cougars logo.svg | logo_size = 150 }} '''Brigham Young University''' ('''BYU''', sometimes referred to colloquially as '''The Y''') is a [[Private education|private]], [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]] [[research university]] in [[Provo, Utah]], United States completely owned by [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church) and run under the auspices of its [[Church Educational System]]. Approximately 99 percent of the students are members of the LDS Church and one-third of its U.S. students are from Utah.{{cite web|title=Y Facts - Demographics |publisher=BYU.edu |year=2015 |url=http://yfacts.byu.edu/Article?id=135 |accessdate=April 20, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150424094326/http://yfacts.byu.edu/Article?id=135 |archivedate=April 24, 2015 }} The university's primary focus is on [[undergraduate education]], but it also has 68 [[master's degree|master's]] and 25 [[doctoral degree]] programs. Students attending BYU agree to follow an [[Church Educational System Honor Code|honor code]], which mandates behavior in line with LDS teachings such as academic honesty, adherence to dress and grooming standards, and abstinence from extramarital sex and from the consumption of drugs and alcohol.{{cite web |title=Honor Code |url=http://www.besmart.com/honorcode |publisher=[[Church Educational System]] |date=February 20, 2015 |accessdate=February 20, 2015}} The university curriculum includes religious education, with required courses in, the Bible (KJV), LDS scripture, doctrine, and history,{{Cite web|url=https://religion.byu.edu/religion-requirements|title=BYU Religion Credit Requirements {{!}} Religious Education|website=religion.byu.edu|language=en|access-date=February 21, 2018}} and the university sponsors [https://speeches.byu.edu weekly devotional assemblies] with most speakers addressing religious topics. Many students (88 percent of men, 39 percent of women) either delay enrollment or take a hiatus from their studies to serve as [[Missionary (LDS Church)|LDS missionaries]].{{cite web|title=Wave of returning missionaries brings BYU enrollment back up|url=http://news.byu.edu/news/fall-2016-enrollment-nearly-40-percent-female-students-have-served-mission|publisher=Brigham Young University|accessdate=October 1, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160930150841/http://news.byu.edu/news/fall-2016-enrollment-nearly-40-percent-female-students-have-served-mission|archive-date=September 30, 2016|dead-url=yes}} An education at BYU is also less expensive than at similar private universities,{{cite web|title=Chapter 3: Postsecondary Education|url=http://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d10/ch_3.asp|work=Digest of Education Statistics: 2010|publisher=U.S. Department of Education|accessdate=June 30, 2011}} since "a significant portion" of the cost of operating the university is subsidized by the church's [[tithe|tithing]] funds.{{cite web|url=http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=85|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080608222135/http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=85|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 8, 2008|title=Tuition|publisher=BYU|accessdate=June 27, 2012}} BYU offers a variety of academic programs, including [[liberal arts]], engineering, agriculture, management, physical and mathematical sciences, nursing, and law. The university is broadly organized into 11 colleges or schools at its main Provo campus, with certain colleges and divisions defining their own admission standards. The university also administers two satellite campuses, [[BYU Jerusalem Center|one in Jerusalem]] and [[BYU Salt Lake Center|one in Salt Lake City]], while its parent organization, the Church Educational System (CES), sponsors sister schools in [[Brigham Young University–Hawaii|Hawaii]] and [[Brigham Young University–Idaho|Idaho]]. BYU's athletic teams compete in [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] and are collectively known as the [[BYU Cougars]]. Their [[BYU Cougars football|college football team]] is an [[NCAA Division I FBS independent schools|NCAA Division I Independent]], while their other sports teams compete in either the [[West Coast Conference]] or [[Mountain Pacific Sports Federation]]. BYU's sports teams have won a total of fourteen national championships. == History == {{Main|History of Brigham Young University}} [[File:BrighamYoung1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Brigham Young]], the school's [[eponym]].]] === Early days === Brigham Young University's origin can be traced back to 1862 when a man named [[Warren Newton Dusenberry|Warren Dusenberry]] started a Provo school in Cluff Hall, a prominent adobe building in the northeast corner of 200 East and 200 North.{{cite news |first = D. Robert |last = Carter |url = http://old.heraldextra.com/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=53358 |title = The hall the Cluffs built |work = The Daily Herald |date = April 24, 2005 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185445/http://old.heraldextra.com/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=53358 |archivedate = September 30, 2007 |df = mdy-all }}. After some financial difficulties the school was recreated in the Kinsey and Lewis buildings on Center street in Provo, and after gaining some recognition for its quality, was adopted to become the Timpanogos branch of the [[University of Deseret]]. When financial difficulty forced another closure, on October 16, 1875, [[Brigham Young]], then [[President of the Church (LDS Church)|president]] of the LDS Church, deeded the property to trustees to create ''Brigham Young Academy'' after earlier hinting a school would be built in Draper, Utah, in 1867.{{cite web|title=BYU: The "almost" college of Draper, Utah |url=http://www.russpage.net/byu-the-almost-college-of-draper-utah/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021233018/https://www.russpage.net/byu-the-almost-college-of-draper-utah/ |archivedate=October 21, 2014 }} Hence, October 16, 1875, is commonly held as BYU's founding date.{{cite web| title =Brigham Young High School History: 1869 to 1903 - The Founding Years | publisher =Brigham Young High School| url =http://abc.eznettools.net/D300015/X329586/History/HistoryDecades/From1869to1903.html| accessdate = August 19, 2007 }} . Brigham Young had been envisioning for several years the concept of a church university The first hundred years, Ernest L. Wilkinson, vol. 1 pg. 61-65 https://ia800501.us.archive.org/18/items/brighamyounguniv01wilk/brighamyounguniv01wilk_bw.pdf. Said Young about his vision: "I hope to see an Academy established in Provo... at which the children of the Latter-day Saints can receive a good education unmixed with the pernicious atheistic influences that are found in so many of the higher schools of the country." [[File:Brigham Young Academy.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The Brigham Young Academy building circa 1900]] Brigham Young Academy {{cite news|first=Sarah |last=Bills |url=http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/43900 |title=Warren Dusenberry (1875 - 1876) |work=BYU NewsNet |date=April 16, 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207182134/http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/43900 |archivedate=February 7, 2012 }} classes commenced on January 3, 1876. Warren Dusenberry served as interim principal for several months until April 1876 when Brigham Young's choice for principal arrived—a German immigrant named [[Karl G. Maeser|Karl Maeser]]. Under Maeser's direction, the school educated many luminaries including future U.S. Supreme Court Justice [[George Sutherland]] and future U.S. Senator [[Reed Smoot]]. The school, however, did not become a university until the end of [[Benjamin Cluff]]'s term at the helm of the institution. At that time, the school was also still privately supported by members of the community and was not absorbed and sponsored officially by the LDS Church until July 18, 1896.{{cite web| title =From 1903 to 1920 ~ A High School Within a University| work =Brigham Young High School History| publisher =Brigham Young High School| year= 2007| url =http://www.byhigh.org/History/HistoryDecades/From1903to1920.html| accessdate = August 20, 2007 }} A series of odd managerial decisions by Cluff led to his demotion; however, in his last official act, he proposed to the Board the Academy be named "Brigham Young University". The suggestion received a large amount of opposition, with many members of the Board saying the school wasn't large enough to be a university, but the decision ultimately passed. One opponent to the decision, Anthon H. Lund, later said, "I hope their head will grow big enough for their hat." In 1903 Brigham Young Academy was dissolved, and was replaced by two institutions: [[Brigham Young High School]], and Brigham Young University. The BY High School class of 1907 was ultimately responsible for the [[hillside letters|famous giant "Y"]] that is to this day [[Y Mountain|embedded on a mountain]] near campus. The Board elected [[George H. Brimhall]] as the new President of BYU. He had not received a high school education until he was forty. Nevertheless, he was an excellent orator and organizer. Under his tenure in 1904 the new Brigham Young University bought {{convert|17|acre|m2}} of land from Provo called "Temple Hill". After some controversy among locals over BYU's purchase of this property, construction began in 1909 on the first building on the current campus, the Karl G. Maeser Memorial.{{cite web| title =History| work =About BYU| publisher =BYU.edu| year =2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/about/default.aspx?content=history| accessdate =August 20, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070922233053/http://unicomm.byu.edu/about/default.aspx?content=history| archivedate =September 22, 2007| df =mdy-all}} Brimhall also presided over the University during a brief crisis involving the theory of evolution. The religious nature of the school seemed at the time to collide with this scientific theory. [[Joseph F. Smith]], LDS Church president, settled the question for a time by asking that evolution not be taught at the school. A few have described the school at this time as nothing more than a "religious seminary". However, many of its graduates at this time would go on to great success and become well renowned in their fields. === Expansion === [[File:Smoot Building.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The Abraham O. Smoot Administration Building]] [[Franklin S. Harris]] was appointed the university's president in 1921. He was the first BYU president to have a doctoral degree. Harris made several important changes to the school, reorganizing it into a true university, whereas before, its organization had remnants of the Academy days. At the beginning of his tenure, the school was not officially recognized as a university by any accreditation organization. By the end of his term, the school was accredited under all major accrediting organizations at the time. He was replaced by [[Howard S. McDonald]], who received his doctorate from the [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]]. When he first received the position, the [[Second World War]] had just ended, and thousands of students were flooding into BYU. By the end of his stay, the school had grown nearly five times to 5,440 students. The university did not have the facilities to handle such a large influx, so he bought part of an Air Force Base in [[Ogden, Utah]] and rebuilt it to house some of the students. The next president, [[Ernest L. Wilkinson]], also oversaw a period of intense growth, as the school adopted an accelerated building program. Wilkinson was responsible for the building of over eighty structures on the campus, many of which still stand.{{cite web| title =Ernest L. Wilkinson| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year =2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/wilkinson.aspx| accessdate =August 20, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070715073422/http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/wilkinson.aspx| archivedate =July 15, 2007| df =mdy-all}} During his tenure, the student body increased six-fold, making BYU the largest private school at the time. The quality of the students also increased, leading to higher educational standards at the school.{{cite web |last=Wilkinson |first=Ernest L. |title=Highlights in the Ninety-Nine-Year History of BYU |publisher=Brigham Young University Press |date=October 10, 1974 |url=http://speeches.byu.edu/reader/reader.php?id=6112 |accessdate=August 19, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817174000/http://speeches.byu.edu/reader/reader.php?id=6112 |archivedate=August 17, 2007 |df= }} Finally, Wilkinson reorganized the LDS Church units on campus, with ten [[Stake (Latter Day Saints)|stakes]] and over 100 [[Ward (LDS Church)|wards]] being added during his administration. [[File:BYU Campus North.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Overlooking North Campus]] [[Dallin H. Oaks]] replaced Wilkinson as president in 1971. Oaks continued the expansion of his predecessor, adding a law school and proposing plans for a new School of Management. During his administration, a new library was also added, doubling the library space on campus.{{cite web| title =Dallin H. Oaks| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year =2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/oaks.aspx| accessdate =August 20, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070715073534/http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/oaks.aspx| archivedate =July 15, 2007| df =mdy-all}} [[Jeffrey R. Holland]] followed as president in 1980, encouraging a combination of educational excellence and religious faith at the university. He believed one of the school's greatest strengths was its religious nature and this should be taken advantage of rather than hidden. During his administration, the university added a campus in Jerusalem, now called the [[BYU Jerusalem Center]]. In 1989, Holland was replaced by [[Rex E. Lee]].{{cite web| title =Jeffrey R. Holland| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year =2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/holland.aspx| accessdate =August 20, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070715073428/http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/holland.aspx| archivedate =July 15, 2007| df =mdy-all}} Lee was responsible for the Benson Science Building and the Museum of Art on campus.{{cite web| title =Rex E. Lee| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year =2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/lee.aspx| accessdate =August 20, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070715073449/http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/lee.aspx| archivedate =July 15, 2007| df =mdy-all}} A cancer victim, Lee is memorialized annually at BYU during a cancer fundraiser called the Rex Lee Run.{{cite web| title =Rex Lee Run| url =http://rexleerun.byu.edu/honorinfo.php| accessdate =August 20, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070701230812/http://rexleerun.byu.edu/honorinfo.php| archivedate =July 1, 2007| df =mdy-all}} Shortly before his death, Lee was replaced in 1995 by [[Merrill J. Bateman]].{{cite web| title =Merrill J. Bateman| work =Presidents| publisher =BYU.edu| year =2007| url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/bateman.aspx| accessdate =August 20, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070715073547/http://unicomm.byu.edu/president/bateman.aspx| archivedate =July 15, 2007| df =mdy-all}} Bateman was responsible for the building of 36 new buildings for the university both on and off campus, including the expansion of the Harold B. Lee Library. He was also one of several key college leaders who brought about the creation of the [[Mountain West Conference]], which BYU's athletics program joined — BYU previously participated in the [[Western Athletic Conference]]. A [[BYU TV|BYU satellite TV network]] also opened in 2000 under his leadership. Bateman was also president during the [[September 11th attacks]] in 2001. The planes crashed on a Tuesday, hours before the weekly devotional normally held at BYU. Previous plans for the devotional were altered, as Bateman led the student body in a prayer for peace.{{cite web| last =Carter| first =Jane| author2 =Marla Sowards| title =President leaves mark on campus| publisher =BYU Newsnet| date =April 16, 2003| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/43904| accessdate =August 20, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071118194458/http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/43904| archivedate =November 18, 2007| df =mdy-all}} Bateman was followed by [[Cecil O. Samuelson]] in 2003.{{cite web| last =Bardsley| first =Ann Jardine| title =BYU's Utah Man| work =Continuum| publisher =Utah.edu| year =2003| url =http://www.alumni.utah.edu/continuum/fall03/byu.htm| accessdate =June 14, 2008| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090115204804/http://www.alumni.utah.edu/continuum/fall03/byu.htm| archivedate =January 15, 2009| df =mdy-all}} Samuelson was succeeded by [[Kevin J Worthen]] in 2014.{{cite news |last=Walch|first=Tad|title=New BYU president: Kevin Worthen to replace Cecil Samuelson|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865598412/New-BYU-president-Kevin-Worthen-to-replace-Cecil-Samuelson.html|accessdate=May 1, 2014|newspaper=Deseret News|date=March 11, 2014}} == Campus == {{Main|Brigham Young University campus|List of Brigham Young University buildings}}[[File:BYU mountain view.JPG|thumb|right|250px|BYU campus with Y mountain and Squaw Peak in the background]] The main campus in [[Provo, Utah]], [[United States]] sits on approximately {{convert|560|acre|km2}} nestled at the base of the [[Wasatch Mountains]] and includes 295 buildings.{{cite web| title =Campus| work =About BYU| publisher =BYU.edu| year =2007| url =http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=133| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20090315055853/http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=133| dead-url =yes| archive-date =March 15, 2009| accessdate =September 18, 2009}} The buildings feature a wide variety of architectural styles, each building being built in the style of its time. The grass, trees, and flower beds on BYU's campus are impeccably maintained.{{cite news |first = Tad |last = Walch |url = http://deseretnews.com/dn/print/1,1442,600144927,00.html |archive-url = https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20131021165207/http://www.deseretnews.com/home/ |dead-url = yes |archive-date = October 21, 2013 |title = Y.'s beauty wows judges |work = Deseret Morning News |date = June 29, 2005 |accessdate = June 23, 2006 |df = mdy-all }}{{cite news |first = Tad |last = Walch |url = http://deseretnews.com/dn/print/1,1442,615154952,00.html |archive-url = https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20131021165207/http://www.deseretnews.com/home/ |dead-url = yes |archive-date = October 21, 2013 |title = New parking lot at BYU won't be ugly expanse |work = Deseret Morning News |date = October 3, 2005 |accessdate = June 23, 2006 |df = mdy-all }} Furthermore, views of the Wasatch Mountains, (including [[Mount Timpanogos]]) can be seen from the campus. BYU's [[Harold B. Lee Library]] (also known as "HBLL"), which ''[[The Princeton Review]]'' ranked as the No. 1 "Great College Library" in 2004,{{cite web | title =Library in the News: September 2004| work =Library in the News| publisher =BYU.edu| date= February 10, 2006| url =http://www.lib.byu.edu/news/2004_09.html| accessdate = August 21, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071118203231/http://www.lib.byu.edu/news/2004_09.html |archivedate = November 18, 2007|deadurl=yes}} has approximately 8.5 million items in its collections, contains {{convert|98|mi|km}} of shelving, and can seat 4,600 people.{{cite web| title =History of the Library| publisher =Brigham Young University| date =March 15, 2006| url =http://www.lib.byu.edu/libhistory.html| accessdate =August 21, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071105200126/http://www.lib.byu.edu/libhistory.html| archivedate =November 5, 2007| df =mdy-all}} The [[Spencer W. Kimball Tower]], shortened to SWKT and pronounced Swicket by many students, is home to several of the university's departments and programs and is the tallest building in Provo, Utah.{{cite web| title =Kimball Tower| work =High-rise Buildings| publisher =Emporis | url =http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=kimballtower-provo-ut-usa| accessdate = }}{{cite web| title =Campus Information| publisher =Brigham Young University | url =http://unicomm.byu.edu/directories/bldg.aspx?id=SWKT| accessdate = April 7, 2007 }} Furthermore, BYU's [[Marriott Center]], used as a basketball arena, can seat over 19,000 and is one of the largest on-campus arenas in the nation.Knupke, Gene. Profiles of American / Canadian Sports Stadiums and Arenas. S.L.: Xlibris Corporation, 2001. pg. 301 {{ISBN|1-4134-9823-X}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}} Absent on the campus of this church owned university is a campus chapel. Notwithstanding, each Sunday LDS Church services for students are conducted on campus, but due to the large number of students attending these services, nearly all of the buildings and possible meeting spaces on campus are utilized (in addition, many students attend services off campus in LDS chapels in the surrounding communities).[http://plantwo.byu.edu/churchweb/pages/sundaymeeting.html]{{dead link|date=July 2013}}{{cite news |author= Photography by Bradley H. Slade| title = Sunday at School | work = BYU Magazine | publisher = Brigham Young University| pages = 26–31| date = Spring 2007}} === Museums === [[File:MOA North entrance.JPG|thumb|right|[[Brigham Young University Museum of Art|Museum of Art]] north entrance]] The campus is home to several museums containing exhibits from many different fields of study. BYU's [[Brigham Young University Museum of Art|Museum of Art]], for example, is one of the largest and most attended art museums in the Mountain West. This museum aids in academic pursuits of students at BYU via research and study of the artworks in its collection. The museum is also open to the general public and provides educational programming.{{cite web| title =About the Museum| work =Brigham Young University Museum of Art| publisher =Brigham Young University| date= September 28, 2006| url =http://moa.byu.edu/index.php?id=50| accessdate = August 21, 2007 }} [[Brigham Young University Museum of Peoples and Cultures|The Museum of Peoples and Cultures]] is a museum of archaeology and ethnology. It focuses on native cultures and artifacts of the Great Basin, American Southwest, Mesoamerica, Peru, and Polynesia. Home to more than 40,000 artifacts and 50,000 photographs, it documents BYU's archaeological research.{{cite web| title =Collections| work =Museum of Peoples and Cultures| publisher =Brigham Young University| date =July 12, 2008| url =http://mpc.byu.edu/Research/Collections.dhtml| accessdate =July 12, 2008| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20080511161245/http://mpc.byu.edu/Research/Collections.dhtml| archivedate =May 11, 2008| df =mdy-all}} The [[BYU Museum of Paleontology]][http://cpms.byu.edu/ESM/index.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070607231555/http://cpms.byu.edu/ESM/index.html|date=June 7, 2007}} was built in 1976 to display the many fossils found by BYU's [[James A. Jensen]]. It holds many vertebrate fossils from the [[Jurassic Period|Jurassic]] and Cretaceous periods, and is one of the top five vertebrate fossil collections in the world from the Jurassic. The museum receives about 25,000 visitors every year.{{cite web|title=Museum Information |work=BYU Earth Science Museum |publisher=Brigham Young University |date=October 26, 2006 |url=http://cpms.byu.edu/ESM/information.html |accessdate=August 21, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815023403/http://cpms.byu.edu/ESM/information.html |archivedate=August 15, 2007 |df= }}{{cite web| title =On Display at the Museum| work =BYU Earth Science Museum| publisher =Brigham Young University| date =October 26, 2006| url =http://cpms.byu.edu/ESM/index.html| accessdate =August 21, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070607231555/http://cpms.byu.edu/ESM/index.html| archivedate =June 7, 2007| df =mdy-all}} The [[Monte L. Bean Life Science Museum]] was formed in 1978. It features several forms of plant and animal life on display and available for research by students and scholars.{{cite web| title =Museum Description| work =Monte L. Bean Museum of Life Science| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://mlbean.byu.edu/home/page/Description.aspx | accessdate = August 21, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070701001829/http://mlbean.byu.edu/home/page/Description.aspx |archivedate = July 1, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The campus also houses several performing arts facilities. The de Jong Concert Hall seats 1282 people and is named for [[Gerrit de Jong Jr.]] The Pardoe Theatre is named for T. Earl and Kathryn Pardoe. Students use its stage in a variety of theatre experiments, as well as for Pardoe Series performances. It seats 500 people, and has quite a large stage with a [[proscenium]] opening of 19 by {{convert|55|ft|m}}.{{cite web| title =Facilities| work =College of Fine Arts and Communications| publisher =Brigham Young University| date= July 27, 2007 | url =http://tma.byu.edu/index.php?id=609| accessdate = August 21, 2007 }} The Margetts Theatre was named for Philip N. Margetts, a prominent Utah theatre figure. A smaller, [[black box theater]], it allows a variety of seating and staging formats. It seats 125, and measures 30 by {{convert|50|ft|m}}. The Nelke Theatre, named for one of BYU's first drama teachers, is used largely for instruction in experimental theater. It seats 280. === Student housing === [[File:ForeignLanguageHousing.JPG|thumb|right|Foreign Language Student Residence, where students commit to speak only their language of study]] Single students who are freshmen have four options for on-campus housing: Heritage Halls, Helaman Halls, Wyview Park, and the Foreign Language Student Residence (FLSR). On-campus married students live in Wymount Terrace or Wyview Park. Heritage Halls was a twenty-four-building housing complex on campus which offers apartment-style living. It has been replaced by a newer housing complex. The halls house both male and female students, divided by gender into separate buildings. Each building has ten to fourteen units capable of housing six people each. Helaman Halls is a slightly newer complex which underwent a 12-year renovation between 1991 and 2004.{{cite web| last =Chamberlin| first =Sarah| title =A new home: Helaman Halls construction completed| publisher =BYU Newsnet| date =September 30, 2003| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/45808| accessdate =August 21, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20031009013606/http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/45808| archivedate =October 9, 2003| df =mdy-all}} Helaman Halls is a nine-building (ninth opened in the summer of 2010), dormitory-style living area. Residents share a room (larger than Heritage Halls) with one other resident, but do not have their own kitchen and use shared bathrooms. Residents are required to have a meal plan, and eat at the newly remodeled Commons at the Cannon Center.{{cite web|url=http://www.byu.edu/oncampushousing/rooms/room_options.shtml|title=BYU On-Campus Housing: Room Options|date=October 23, 2007|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20071228065028/http://www.byu.edu/oncampushousing/rooms/room_options.shtml#helaman|archivedate=December 28, 2007}} Wyview Park was originally built for families in 1996, but this changed in 2006 when the complex began housing single students in order to counteract loss of singles' housing in other areas.{{cite web| last =Schaerr| first =Stephanie| title =Single Students Move in to Wyview| publisher =BYU Newsnet| date =September 5, 2006| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/60723| accessdate =August 21, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071118203500/http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/60723| archivedate =November 18, 2007| df =mdy-all}} Wyview Park has 30 buildings that offer apartment-style living for students, along with the option for shared or single rooms. The Foreign Language Student Residence complex has twenty-five apartments where students speak exclusively in a selected foreign language. The immersion experience is available in nine languages, and students are accompanied by a native resident throughout the year to enhance the experience.{{cite web| title =BYU Housing - FLSR Info| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://flsr.byu.edu/about.php| accessdate =August 21, 2007| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20070808034637/http://flsr.byu.edu/about.php| archive-date =August 8, 2007| dead-url =yes| df =mdy-all}} Married students can house in Wymount Terrace, which contains a total of 462 apartments in 24 buildings.{{cite web| title =Wymount Terrace, 1960s| work =BYU Campus Photographs| publisher =Brigham young University| url =http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/BYUPhotos&CISOPTR=692&CISOBOX=1&REC=3| accessdate = August 21, 2007 }} Branches of the [[BYU Creamery]] provide basic food and general grocery products for students living in Heritage Halls, Helaman, Wymount, Wyview, and the FLSR. Helaman Halls is also served by a central cafeteria called the Cannon Center.{{cite web| title =Room Options| work =On-Campus Housing| publisher =Brigham young University | url =http://www.byu.edu/oncampushousing/rooms.html#heritage_halls| accessdate = August 21, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070822224947/http://www.byu.edu/oncampushousing/rooms.html |archivedate = August 22, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The creamery, begun in 1949, has become a BYU tradition and is also frequented by visitors to the university and members of the community.{{cite web| last =Moss| first =Michael| title =Sweet Creams: BYU Creamery a Campus Landmark Since 1949| date =May 30, 2007| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/64478| accessdate =August 21, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070914025210/http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/64478| archivedate =September 14, 2007| df =mdy-all}} It was the first on-campus full-service grocery store in the country.{{cite web| last =Woodland| first =Mark| title =Creamery on Ninth declared "Good Neighbor"| publisher =BYU Newsnet| date =July 26, 2006| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/60499| accessdate =August 21, 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071118203454/http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/60499| archivedate =November 18, 2007| df =mdy-all}} === Sustainability === BYU has designated energy conservation, products and materials, recycling, site planning and building design, student involvement, transportation, water conservation, and zero waste events as top priority categories in which to further its efforts to be an environmentally sustainable campus. The university has stated "we have a responsibility to be wise stewards of the earth and its resources."{{cite web| title =Y Facts - Sustainability| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://sustainability.byu.edu| accessdate = March 25, 2014}} BYU is working to increase the energy efficiency of its buildings by installing various speed drives on all pumps and fans, replacing incandescent lighting with fluorescent lighting, retrofitting campus buildings with low-E reflective glass, and upgraded roof insulation to prevent heat loss.{{cite web |title=Energy Conservation |publisher=Brigham Young University |url=http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=256 |accessdate=June 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626160806/https://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=256 |archivedate=June 26, 2010 }} The student groups BYU Recycles, Eco-Response, and BYU Earth educate students, faculty, staff, and administrators about how the campus can decrease its environmental impact. BYU Recycles spearheaded the recent campaign to begin recycling plastics, which the university did after a year of student campaigning.{{cite web |title=Student Involvement |publisher=Brigham Young University |url=http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=260 |accessdate=June 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090523162307/http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=260 |archivedate=May 23, 2009 }}{{cite web| title =BYU Newsnet - Going Toward the Green| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/72130| accessdate =June 8, 2009| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110202041024/http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/72130| archivedate =February 2, 2011| df =mdy-all}} == Organization and administration == {| class="toccolours" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; font-size:90%; line-height:1.4em; width:300px;" ! colspan="2" style="text-align: center;" | '''College/school founding''' |- | '''College/school''' || '''Year founded''' |- | colspan="2" |
|- | [[Marriott School of Management|Business (Marriott)]] || 1891 |- | [[David O. McKay School of Education|Education (McKay)]] || 1913 |- | [[Ira A. Fulton College of Engineering and Technology|Engineering and Technology (Fulton)]] || 1953 |- | [[BYU College of Family, Home and Social Sciences|Family, Home, and Social Sciences]] || 1969 |- | [[BYU College of Fine Arts and Communications|Fine Arts and Communications]] || 1925 |- | [[BYU College of Humanities|Humanities]] || 1965 |- | [[J. Reuben Clark Law School|Law (Clark)]] || 1973 |- | [[BYU College of Life Sciences|Life Sciences]] || 1954 |- | [[BYU College of Nursing|Nursing]] || 1953 |- | [[BYU College of Physical and Mathematical Sciences|Physical and Mathematical Sciences]] || 1949 |- | [[BYU College of Religious Education|Religious Education]] || 1959 |} Brigham Young University is a part of the LDS [[Church Educational System]]. It is organized under a [[Board of Trustees]], with the President of the Church (currently [[Russell M. Nelson]]) as chairman. This board consists of the same people as the Church Board of Education, a pattern that has been in place since 1939. Prior to 1939, BYU had a separate board of trustees that was subordinate to the Church Board of Education.Wilkinson, Ernest L., ''Brigham Young University: The First 100 Years''. (Provo: BYU Press, 1975) Vol. 2 The President of BYU, currently [[Kevin J Worthen]], reports to the Board, through the Commissioner of Education.{{cite web| title =Administration| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2007-2008ucat/pdfportions/103admin.pdf| accessdate =July 25, 2007| format =PDF| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070927051805/http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2007-2008ucat/pdfportions/103admin.pdf| archivedate =September 27, 2007| df =mdy-all}} The university operates under 11 colleges or schools, which collectively offer 194 bachelor's degree programs, 68 master's degree programs, 25 PhD programs, and a [[Juris Doctor]] program.{{cite web |title=Academic Organization |work=About BYU |publisher=Brigham Young University |url=http://unicomm.byu.edu/about/default.aspx?content=academic-organization |accessdate=August 24, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070921224236/http://unicomm.byu.edu/about/default.aspx?content=academic-organization |archivedate=September 21, 2007 }} BYU also manages some courses and majors through the [[David M. Kennedy Center for International Studies]]{{cite web| title =David M. Kennedy Center Home Page| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://kennedy.byu.edu/| accessdate = August 24, 2007 }} and "miscellaneous" college departments, including Undergraduate Education,{{cite web| title =Undergraduate Education| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://ue.byu.edu/| accessdate = August 24, 2007 }} Graduate Studies,{{cite web | title =Graduate Studies| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://www.byu.edu/gradstudies/| accessdate = August 24, 2007 }} Independent Study,{{cite web| title =Independent Study| publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://ce.byu.edu/is/site/| accessdate = August 24, 2007 }} Continuing Education,{{cite web| title =Division of Continuing Education | publisher =Brigham Young University| url =http://ce.byu.edu/home/| accessdate = August 24, 2007 }} and the Honors Program.[http://honors.byu.edu/ Index], honors.byu.edu BYU's Winter semester ends earlier than most universities in April since there is no [[Spring break]], thus allowing students to pursue internships and other summer activities earlier.{{cite web |last=Buchanan |first=Adam |title=No Break for BYU Students |publisher=BYU Newsnet |date=March 20, 2007 |url=http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/63637 |accessdate=August 24, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071118203510/http://newsnet.byu.edu/story.cfm/63637 |archivedate=November 18, 2007 |df= }} A typical academic year is broken up into two semesters: Fall (September–December) and Winter (January–April), as well as two shorter terms during the summer months: Spring (May–June) and Summer (July–August). == Academics == === Admissions and demographics === BYU accepted 53.4 percent of the 13,731 people who applied for admission in the spring and summer terms, and fall semester of 2017.{{cite web|url=https://admissions.byu.edu/entrance-averages|title=Admission:Entrance Averages|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Brigham Young University|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171129224821/https://admissions.byu.edu/entrance-averages|archivedate=November 29, 2017|deadurl=yes|access-date=November 29, 2017}} The average GPA for these admitted students was 3.86 with an average [[ACT (test)|ACT]] of 29.5 and [[SAT]] of 1300. ''U.S. News and World Report'' describes BYU's selectivity as being "more selective" and compares it with such universities as the [[University of Texas at Austin]] and [[Ohio State University|The Ohio State University]].{{cite web |title=Brigham Young University–Provo |publisher=U.S. News and World Report |year=2007 |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/directory/brief/drglance_3670_brief.php |accessdate=July 25, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070808135125/http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/directory/brief/drglance_3670_brief.php |archivedate=August 8, 2007 }}{{cite web|title=University of Texas-Austin |publisher=U.S. News and World Report |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/directory/brief/drglance_3658_brief.php |accessdate=July 25, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070716033256/http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/directory/brief/drglance_3658_brief.php |archivedate=July 16, 2007 }} In the case of University of Texas-Austin ("UT"), BYU appears to be more selective in some regards, with 27 percent of admitted freshmen having ACT scores over 30, as compared with 23 percent for UT.{{cite web|title=The University of Texas at Austin |publisher=Peterson's |url=http://education.yahoo.com/college/facts/9414.html |accessdate=July 25, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703131131/http://education.yahoo.com/college/facts/9414.html |archivedate=July 3, 2007 }}{{cite web|title=Ohio State University-Columbus |publisher=U.S. News and World Report |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/directory/brief/drglance_6883_brief.php |accessdate=July 25, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070808134306/http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/directory/brief/drglance_6883_brief.php |archivedate=August 8, 2007 }} In addition, BYU is ranked 26th in colleges with the most freshman [[National Merit Scholarship Program|Merit Scholars]], with 88 in 2006.The Chronicle of Higher Education, August 31, 2007. BYU has one of the highest percentage of accepted applicants that go on to enroll (78 percent in 2010).{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/articles/education/best-colleges/2010/03/05/brigham-young-university-is-nations-most-popular-national-university.html|title=USnews.com|work=US News & World Report|accessdate=October 14, 2014}} [[File:Harold B. Lee Library.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The [[Harold B. Lee Library]] is consistently ranked among the top ten in the nation, with a No. 1 ranking in 2004 by ''[[The Princeton Review]]''.]] Students from every state in the U.S. and from many foreign countries attend BYU. (In the 2005–06 academic year, there were 2,396 foreign students, or eight (8) percent of enrollment.) Slightly more than 98 percent of these students are active members of the LDS Church. In 2006, 12.6 percent of the student body reported themselves as ethnic minorities, mostly Asians, Pacific islanders and Hispanics.{{cite web |url=http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=135 |title=About BYU - Demographics |accessdate=August 1, 2008 |publisher=BYU.edu |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080608222029/http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=135 |archivedate=June 8, 2008 }} === Graduation honors === Undergraduate students may qualify for graduation honors. ''[[University Honors]]'' is the highest distinction BYU awards its graduates.{{cite web|url=http://ccc.byu.edu/honors |title=Honors |accessdate=January 21, 2010 |publisher=Brigham Young University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090808191415/http://ccc.byu.edu/honors |archivedate=August 8, 2009 }} Administered by the [[Brigham Young University Honors Program|Honors Program]], the distinction requires students to complete an honors curriculum requirement, a Great Questions requirement, an Experiential Learning requirement, an honors thesis requirement, and a graduation portfolio that summarizes the student's honors experiences.{{cite web|url=http://honors.fye.byu.edu/sites/default/files/student_files/program/NewProgramRequirementsforGraduationwithUniversityHonors6.pdf|title=New Program Requirements|publisher=BYU Honors Program|accessdate=August 5, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007152610/http://honors.fye.byu.edu/sites/default/files/student_files/program/NewProgramRequirementsforGraduationwithUniversityHonors6.pdf|archivedate=October 7, 2013}} The university also awards [[Latin honors|Latin scholastic distinctions]] separately from the Honors Program: ''summa cum laude'' (top 1 percent), ''magna cum laude'' (top 5 percent), and ''cum laude'' (top 10 percent).{{cite web|url=http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/Graduation.php#LatinScholDistinctions |title=BYU Graduation Honors |accessdate=January 21, 2010 |publisher=Brigham Young University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204090836/http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/Graduation.php |archivedate=February 4, 2010 }} The university additionally recognizes [[Phi Kappa Phi]] graduation honors. === Rankings === {{Infobox US university ranking | ARWU_W = 401–500 | ARWU_N = 118–139 | Forbes = 86 | QS_W = 801-1000 | THES_W = | USNWR_NU = 66 | USNWR_W = 601 | Wamo_NU = 21 }} For 2017, ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' ranked BYU as 61st among national universities in the United States.{{cite web |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/byu-3670 |title=Brigham Young University|work=U.S. News Best Colleges Rankings - 2017 |publisher=''U.S. News & World Report'' |accessdate=September 12, 2017 |series=[https://www.usnews.com/best-colleges/rankings/national-universities National University Rankings]}} A 2013 ''[[Quarterly Journal of Economics]]'' study of where the nation's top high school students choose to enroll ranked BYU No. 21 in its peer-reviewed study.{{citation |url= http://qje.oxfordjournals.org/content/128/1/425.abstract |title= A Revealed Preference Ranking of U.S. Colleges and Universities |first1= Christopher N. |last1= Avery |first2= Mark E. |last2= Glickman |first3= Caroline M. |last3= Hoxby |first4= Andrew |last4= Metrick |journal= [[Quarterly Journal of Economics]] |volume= 128 |issue= 1 |pages= 425–467 |doi= 10.1093/qje/qjs043 |publisher= [[Oxford University Press]] |citeseerx= 10.1.1.197.8685 }} ''The Princeton Review'' has ranked BYU the best value for college in 2007,{{cite web |title= Texas State named Best Western College for 2008 |publisher= Texas State University |url= http://www.txstate.edu/about/best-value.html |accessdate= August 30, 2007 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070804173258/http://www.txstate.edu/about/best-value.html |archivedate= August 4, 2007 |deadurl= yes}} and its [[Harold B. Lee Library|library]] is consistently ranked in the nation's top ten — No. 1 in 2004 and No. 4 in 2007.{{cite web |title= Best 361 College Rankings |publisher= ''The Princeton Review'' |url= http://www.princetonreview.com/college/research/profiles/rankings.asp?listing=1023349<ID=1 |accessdate= July 12, 2007 }} BYU is also ranked No. 19 in the ''U.S. News and World Report's'' "Great Schools, Great Prices" lineup, and No. 12 in lowest student-incurred debt.{{cite web|title=Rankings and Recognition |work=About BYU |publisher=Brigham Young University |year=2007 |url=http://unicomm.byu.edu/about/default.aspx?content=rankings-recognition |accessdate=August 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070921045128/http://unicomm.byu.edu/about/default.aspx?content=rankings-recognition |archivedate=September 21, 2007 }} Due in part to the school's emphasis on undergraduate research, in rankings for 2008-2009, BYU was ranked No. 10 nationally for the number of students who go on to earn PhDs, No. 1 nationally for students who go on to dental school, No. 6 nationally for students who go on to law school, and No. 10 nationally for students who go on to medical school.{{cite web|url=http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=181|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080608214149/http://yfacts.byu.edu/viewarticle.aspx?id=181|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 8, 2008|title=Academic Rankings 2008-2009 BYU.edu|publisher=|accessdate=October 14, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://yfacts.byu.edu/Article?id=282|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120705165123/http://yfacts.byu.edu/Article?id=282|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 5, 2012|title=Academic Rankings 2010-2011 BYU.edu (Provided for more recent info, but different format presented)|publisher=|accessdate=October 14, 2014}} BYU is designated as a research university with high research activity by the [[Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching]].{{cite web| title =Brigham Young University| work =Classifications| publisher =Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching| url =http://www.carnegiefoundation.org/classifications/sub.asp?key=748&subkey=16461&start=782| accessdate = July 12, 2007 }} ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine ranked it as the No. 1 "Top University to Work For in 2014"{{cite web| title=The Top 25 Universities To Work For in 2014| publisher =Forbes Magazine| author=Dill, Kathryn |year=2014| accessdate=July 6, 2015 |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kathryndill/2014/09/19/the-top-25-universities-to-work-for-in-2014/}} and as the best college in Utah.{{cite web |last=Howard |first=Caroline |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/carolinehoward/2016/02/22/the-best-college-in-every-state/5/#3201b11619ef |title=The Best College In Every State |date=February 22, 2016 |work=Forbes |accessdate=February 22, 2016}} In 2009 the university's [[Marriott School of Management]] received a No. 5 ranking by ''[[BusinessWeek]]'' for its undergraduate programs,{{cite web|url=http://bwnt.businessweek.com/interactive_reports/undergrad_bschool_2009/|title=Business School Rankings & Profiles|year=2009|author=BusinessWeek|publisher=The McGraw-Hill Companies Inc.|accessdate=December 10, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302061956/http://bwnt.businessweek.com/interactive_reports/undergrad_bschool_2009/|archivedate=March 2, 2009}} and its MBA program was ranked by several sources: No. 22 ranking by ''BusinessWeek'', No. 16 by ''[[Forbes]]'',{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/95/best-business-schools-09_Best-Business-Schools_Rank.html|title=Best Business Schools|publisher=Forbes LLC|work=Forbes.com|accessdate=August 5, 2009|date=August 5, 2009}} and No. 29 by ''U.S. News & World Report''.{{cite web |url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-business-schools/rankings |work=America's Best Graduate Schools |title=Best Business Schools |publisher=U.S. News & World Report |year=2009 |accessdate=May 18, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426153859/http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-business-schools/rankings/ |archivedate=April 26, 2009 }} Among regional schools the MBA program was ranked No. 1 by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'s'' most recent ranking (2007),{{cite web |url=http://www.harrisinteractive.com/services/bschools.asp |title=Wall Street Journal/Harris Interactive Business School Survey |accessdate=May 30, 2008 |publisher=[[Harris Insights & Analytics|Harris Interactive]]}} and it was ranked No. 92 among business schools worldwide in 2009 by ''[[Financial Times]]''.{{cite web|url=http://rankings.ft.com/exportranking/global-mba-rankings/pdf |title=The top full-time US MBA programmes |accessdate=April 22, 2009 |publisher=The Financial Times |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090408012200/http://rankings.ft.com/exportranking/global-mba-rankings/pdf |archivedate=April 8, 2009 |deadurl=no }} For 2009, the university's [[BYU School of Accountancy|School of Accountancy]], which is housed within the Marriott School, received a No. 2https://news.byu.edu/byu-numbers and two No. 3 rankings for its undergraduate program—one by ''[[Public Accounting Report]]'' and the other by ''U.S. News & World Report''.{{cite web | url = http://gmatclub.com/forum/public-accounting-report-2009-ranking-undergrad-ms-phd-88331.html | title = 2009 Accounting Program Rankings | publisher = ''[[Public Accounting Report]]'' |year=2009 | accessdate = January 19, 2010 }}{{cite web | url = http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/spec-accounting | title = Ranking of undergraduate accounting programs | publisher = ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' | year = 2009 | accessdate = January 19, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100310210117/http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/spec-accounting | archivedate = March 10, 2010 | df = mdy-all }} The same two reporting agencies also ranked the school's [[MAcc]] program No. 3 and No. 8 in the nation, respectively.{{cite web | url = http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-business-schools/accounting | title = Ranking of graduate accounting programs | publisher = ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' | year = 2009 | accessdate = January 19, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100309221648/http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-business-schools/accounting | archivedate = March 9, 2010 | df = mdy-all }}{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704554104575435563989873060 |title=The Top 25 Recruiter Picks | work=The Wall Street Journal}} In 2010 an article in the Wall Street Journal listing institutions whose graduates were the top-rated by recruiters ranked BYU No. 11. Using 2010 fiscal year data, the Association of University Technology Managers ranked BYU No. 3 in an evaluation of universities creating the most startup companies through campus research.{{cite web |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700202733/National-report-University-of-Utah-No-1-BYU-No-3-in-tech-startup-companies.html|title=National report: University of Utah No. 1, BYU No. 3 in tech startup companies|date=November 30, 2011|work=DeseretNews.com|accessdate=October 14, 2014}} The BYU [[J. Reuben Clark Law School]]https://law.byu.edu/ has a No. 41 national ranking according to the [[U.S. News & World Report]]https://www.usnews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-law-schools/law-rankings === Notable research and awards === [[File:TNRB Tanner Building.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The [[N. Eldon Tanner Building]], home of the [[Marriott School of Management]]]] Scientists associated with BYU have created some notable inventions. [[Philo T. Farnsworth]], inventor of the electronic television, received his education at BYU, and later returned to do fusion research, receiving an honorary degree from the university.{{cite web | url = http://content.lib.utah.edu/u?/UU_EAD,2160 | archive-url = https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20131021170353/http://content.lib.utah.edu/cdm/ref/collection/UU_EAD/id/2160 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = October 21, 2013 | title = Biography of Philo Taylor Farnsworth | work = | publisher = University of Utah Marriott Library Special Collections | accessdate = July 5, 2007 | df = mdy-all }} Alumnus [[Harvey Fletcher]], inventor of stereophonic sound, went on to carry out the now famous [[oil-drop experiment]] with [[Robert Millikan]], and was later Founding Dean of the [[Ira A. Fulton College of Engineering and Technology|BYU College of Engineering]].{{cite journal | title = My Work with Millikan on the Oil-drop Experiment | author = Harvey Fletcher | journal = Physics Today |date=June 1982 | page = 43 | doi = 10.1063/1.2915126 | volume=35}} [[H. Tracy Hall]], inventor of the [[man-made diamond]], left [[General Electric]] in 1955 and became a full professor of chemistry and Director of Research at BYU. While there, he invented a new type of diamond press, the tetrahedral press. In student achievements, BYU Ad Lab teams won both the 2007 and 2008 [[L'Oréal]] National Brandstorm Competition,{{cite web|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/1,5143,695270519,00.html |title=Y students take first in ad competition |accessdate=May 6, 2008 |work= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080425052304/http://www.deseretnews.com/article/1%2C5143%2C695270519%2C00.html |archivedate=April 25, 2008 |deadurl=no }}{{cite web |url=http://www.brandstorm.loreal.com/Cand/index.html |title=L'Oréal National Brandstorm Competition |accessdate=May 6, 2008 |work= |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080603152030/http://www.brandstorm.loreal.com/Cand/index.html |archivedate = June 3, 2008|deadurl=yes}} and students developed the Magnetic Lasso algorithm found in [[Adobe Photoshop]].{{cite news |first = Lois M. |last = Collins |url = http://www.deseretnews.com/article/640198852/BYU-scientists-create-tool-for-virtual-surgery.html |title = BYU scientists create tool for 'virtual surgery' |work = Deseret Morning News |date= July 31, 2006 |accessdate = February 24, 2013}} In prestigious scholarships, BYU has produced 10 [[Rhodes Scholarship|Rhodes Scholars]],{{cite web |url=http://magazine.byu.edu/?act=view&a=232 |title= Catching up with Former Rhodes Scolars |accessdate=June 13, 2008}} four [[Gates Cambridge Scholarships|Gates Scholars]] in the last six years, and in the last decade has claimed 41 [[Fulbright program|Fulbright scholars]] and 3 [[Jack Kent Cooke]] scholars.{{cite web |url=http://opsf.byu.edu/Scholarships/BYU_Recipients/BYU_Winner_Summary.aspx |title=BYU Winner Summary |accessdate=May 6, 2008 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080427071104/http://opsf.byu.edu/Scholarships/BYU_Recipients/BYU_Winner_Summary.aspx |archivedate=April 27, 2008 }} === Devotionals and forums === To provide students with opportunities for both spiritual and intellectual insight, BYU has hosted weekly devotional and forum assemblies since the school's early days.{{Cite news|url=https://speeches.byu.edu/posts/the-history-of-byu-speeches/|title=The History of BYU Speeches - BYU Speeches|work=BYU Speeches|access-date=February 21, 2018|language=en-US}} Devotionals are most common and address religious topics, often with academic perspective or insight. Devotional speakers are typically drawn from the BYU faculty and administration or LDS Church leadership, including church presidents George Albert Smith, Spencer W. Kimball, and Russell M. Nelson. Several times each year the devotional is replaced by a forum, which typically addresses a more secular topic and may include a speaker from outside the BYU or LDS community. In recent years, forum speakers have included notable politicians (e.g. Joseph Lieberman, Mitt Romney), scientists (Neil deGrasse Tyson, DJ Patil), historians (David McCullough, Richard Beeman), religious leaders (Archbishop Charles Chaput, Albert Mohler), judicial figures (John Roberts, Thomas Griffith) and other thought leaders (Liz Wiseman, Arthur Brooks).
